author: pipermerriam
content: <@!476250636548308992> this is the channel where we've historically discussed solutions for retrieving state history, the previous prototype was called "Alexandria" and uses an overlay DHT on the discovery v5 network.

author: nishant0
content:

https://github.com/ethereum/stateless-ethereum-specs/pull/54/files

author: pipermerriam
content:
No, that one is focused on the ethereum "State" (https://github.com/ethereum/stateless-ethereum-specs/wiki/Glossary#state) which I realize in the glossary is still under the "Chain History" heading, but belongs under it's own heading.

- Chain History: Blocks (transactions & uncles), Receipts, Headers
- State: Accounts and Contract Storage

author: pipermerriam
content:
This is the latest spec document that was produced late last year for Alexandria: https://notes.ethereum.org/oUJE4ZX2Q6eMOgEMiQPkpQ?view

But the real solution is likely to look decently different from that.  The advertisement mechanic turned out to be flawed (massive bottleneck with little upside)

author: pipermerriam
content: <@!476250636548308992> can I ask what the context is for your inquiry?

author: nishant0
content: This was mostly for my curiousity, wanted to look at how chain history would be kept in 1.x , specifically since it would be leveraging discoveryV5

author: nishant0
content: Compared to the spec above for Alexandria , what would be the main changes to it , would it be mostly a change to the advertisement protocol ?

author: pipermerriam
content:
- Full removal of the Advertisement system.  
- Content is found at it's `content_id` location in the network
- Probably elimination of  `hash_tree_root` and in-protocol multi-packet responses in favor of something like minimal implementation of  uTP (https://www.bittorrent.org/beps/bep_0029.html) for streaming larger data payloads between nodes (block bodies can easily be 50kb).

author: pipermerriam
content:
cc <@!476250636548308992> 

And there will be a gossip component that is separate from the DHT, either using libp2p or some version of the uTP protocol if we keep everything constrained to DiscV5 protocols.
